publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: ... for sure my wish may be fulfilled, may I have a pure way of living [lit. living of life] consisting of wisdom by (this three-fold de)ed! Avoiding (suffering) [and] happiness (in) the sharing ...
... (May I avoid the) danger (of the passions), [and] may I always become without anger through this deed! Which [= the Brāhmaṇavarga] makes rain jewels of meanings like the cintāmaṇi gem,

through this excellent writing (of the excellent Brāhmaṇavarga, superior to everything), may I make manifest the noble eightfold path that goes to the city of Nirvāṇa! May [the beings] (of the five births) reach the happiness consisting in the extinction of all sufferings

(through the wish coming from me)! 40. I have written with a great wish the excellent (U)dānavarga (provided with meaning [and] [literary] form, which chases away) the diseases of the passions, the good jewel of the Law, the excellent one, that has been bought by the dear lives of the omniscents as numerous as the grains of sand of the Ganges. May the darkness of ignorance of [the beings] of the five births disappear through this deed! 41. (Having heard the great baskets [i.e., the canonical writings]) that exist through wonder,

Das mit den lieben Leben der dem Sand in der Gaṅgā gleichenden Alleswissenden erkaufte vorzügliche Gesetzesjuwel, das gute, die Kleśa-Krankheiten vertreibende, den herrlichen Udāna[varga], habe ich (sinn- [und] buchstabengetreu [wtl. mit dem Sinn [und] dem Buchstaben an seiner Stelle]) geschrieben in dem großen Wunsche: Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen!

The excellent law-jewel, bought with the dear lives of the Omniscients, alike to the sand in the Gaṅgā, the good one, expelling the kleśa-diseases, the magnificent Udāna[varga] I have written, (faithful in meaning and letter [lit. with the meaning [and] the letter in its place]), greatly wishing: may, through this deed, the darkness of ignorance disappear for the beings of the five incarnations!
Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den Fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen!
Because of this deed, may the darkness of ignorance pass for the beings of the five incarnations!

since for (each) single śloka you [the Buddha] have given by thousands [your] heads to be cut off, [and] to flay your skin from the body, your (energy) did (not) wane to make flow [your] blood, [and your] m(arrow).

(O lord, by selling yourself) blood overflowed out from (e)ighty thousand pores. 42. My spirit arose in order to proclaim the great striving of the good king of Riṣis. Through a speech in Kuchean manner, ...
Es erhob sich in mir der Gedanke, die große Anstrengung des guten Königs der Ṛṣis zu verkünden.
The thought arose in me to proclaim the great effort of the good king of the Ṛṣis.
I myself am (without capac)ity, nevertheless I have taken away this firmness from life [and] body, and I (pro)claim precisley this wish: May I become an omniscient for sure (through) this deed! 43.
Und nur diesen Wunsch verkünde ich: "Möchte ich ganz bestimmt ein Allerkenner werden (durch) diese Tat!"
And this [one] wish only I proclaim: "May I most certainly become an all-perceiving one due to this deed!"

(For the sake of the Law) may I abandon [as lightly] as (grass) my head [and] this (living)! May I become unconcerned [and] may I not care about life, (sen)ses, [and] (bo)dies! May I obtain the support of aware(ness)!
Und möchte ich unbekümmert sein [und] auf Leben, Sinne [und] Körper nicht Rücksicht nehmen.
And may I be unconcerned [and] not consider life, the senses [and] the body.

May (the companion of firmness not lea)ve (me)! With the wish for omniscience I will myself go the way of the (Law) without stop. (44.) May my heart turn into a diamond in order to endure (my own suff)erings!

p.note: 64 only edited lines a4-a5 of the recto side. Part of the text can be restored with the help of = S 7 a 5-b 2. It belongs to the short version of the Udānastotra where the text proper ends with stanza no. 40.

The original has been lost since at least the 1980ies, and since it did not make it into the numbering of the series PK AS even in the 1950ies, it is likely that it was already lost by that time. However, Lévi still used it for his 1933 book.
According to the description of Lévi preserved in his first draft of the 1933 book, the leaf lacks the left part including the string hole.
Note the preservation of word-final -ä of sakwä, which is metrically warranted.

The text is partly restored with the help of b 2, although there we have the finite preterite form paiykāmai of the verb pikā- instead of an abstract. Accordingly, the pāda 40b had no finite verb, which stands in the following pāda.

The missing eleven syllables of pāda 43a probably contained a sentence referring to the composition of the praise of the Udānavarga as being first told by the Buddha in contrast to the actual praise in the Kuchean language.

Lévi had the reading klāwäṣṣi, but such an optative/imperfect forms does not make sense in this passage; the correct form, the infinitive klāwässi has actually been read by Lévi in his first draft. Note that in the glossary on p. 123 Lévi also analyzes the form correctly an infinitive (while still giving the wrong reading with ṣṣi).
Lévi has the wrong form kektseñi in the edited text, but the correct form kektseñän in note 6.

list.item:
[[Lévi 1933]]: 64 only edited lines a4-a5 of the recto side. Part of the text can be restored with the help of [[PK AS 5D]] = S 7 a 5-b 2. It belongs to the short version of the Udānastotra where the text proper ends with stanza no. 40.

a3. The text is partly restored with the help of [[PK AS 5D]] b 2, although there we have the finite preterite form paiykāmai of the verb pikā- instead of an abstract. Accordingly, the pāda 40b had no finite verb, which stands in the following pāda.

b2. The missing eleven syllables of pāda 43a probably contained a sentence referring to the composition of the praise of the Udānavarga as being first told by the Buddha in contrast to the actual praise in the Kuchean language.

b2. Lévi had the reading klāwäṣṣi, but such an optative/imperfect forms does not make sense in this passage; the correct form, the infinitive klāwässi has actually been read by Lévi in his first draft. Note that in the glossary on p. 123 Lévi also analyzes the form correctly an infinitive (while still giving the wrong reading with ṣṣi).

b4. Lévi has the wrong form kektseñi in the edited text, but the correct form kektseñän in note 6.
Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn)
a1. Note the preservation of word-final -ä of sakwä, which is metrically warranted.

Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

a1 ... for sure my wish may be fulfilled, may I have a pure way of living [lit. living of life] consisting of wisdom by (this three-fold de)ed! Avoiding (suffering) [and] happiness (in) the sharing ... a2 ... (May I avoid the) danger (of the passions), [and] may I always become without anger through this deed! Which [= the Brāhmaṇavarga] makes rain jewels of meanings like the cintāmaṇi gem, a3 through this excellent writing (of the excellent Brāhmaṇavarga, superior to everything), may I make manifest the noble eightfold path that goes to the city of Nirvāṇa! May [the beings] (of the five births) reach the happiness consisting in the extinction of all sufferings a4-a5 (through the wish coming from me)! 40. I have written with a great wish the excellent (U)dānavarga (provided with meaning [and] [literary] form, which chases away) the diseases of the passions, the good jewel of the Law, the excellent one, that has been bought by the dear lives of the omniscents as numerous as the grains of sand of the Ganges. May the darkness of ignorance of [the beings] of the five births disappear through this deed! 41. (Having heard the great baskets [i.e., the canonical writings]) that exist through wonder, b1 since for (each) single śloka you [the Buddha] have given by thousands [your] heads to be cut off, [and] to flay your skin from the body, your (energy) did (not) wane to make flow [your] blood, [and your] m(arrow). b2 (O lord, by selling yourself) blood overflowed out from (e)ighty thousand pores. 42. My spirit arose in order to proclaim the great striving of the good king of Riṣis. Through a speech in Kuchean manner, ... b3 I myself am (without capac)ity, nevertheless I have taken away this firmness from life [and] body, and I (pro)claim precisley this wish: May I become an omniscient for sure (through) this deed! 43. b4 (For the sake of the Law) may I abandon [as lightly] as (grass) my head [and] this (living)! May I become unconcerned [and] may I not care about life, (sen)ses, [and] (bo)dies! May I obtain the support of aware(ness)! b5 May (the companion of firmness not lea)ve (me)! With the wish for omniscience I will myself go the way of the (Law) without stop. (44.) May my heart turn into a diamond in order to endure (my own suff)erings!

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a4-5 Das mit den lieben Leben der dem Sand in der Gaṅgā gleichenden Alleswissenden erkaufte vorzügliche Gesetzesjuwel, das gute, die Kleśa-Krankheiten vertreibende, den herrlichen Udāna[varga], habe ich (sinn- [und] buchstabengetreu [wtl. mit dem Sinn [und] dem Buchstaben an seiner Stelle]) geschrieben in dem großen Wunsche: Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen! 452
a5 Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den Fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen! 128-9
b2 Es erhob sich in mir der Gedanke, die große Anstrengung des guten Königs der Ṛṣis zu verkünden. 75-6
b3 Und nur diesen Wunsch verkünde ich: "Möchte ich ganz bestimmt ein Allerkenner werden (durch) diese Tat!" 249
b4 Und möchte ich unbekümmert sein [und] auf Leben, Sinne [und] Körper nicht Rücksicht nehmen. 323

The original has been lost since at least the 1980ies, and since it did not make it into the numbering of the series PK AS even in the 1950ies, it is likely that it was already lost by that time. However, Lévi still used it for his 1933 book.

According to the description of Lévi preserved in his first draft of the 1933 book, the leaf lacks the left part including the string hole.
